utterances: And came back.
...on trips and, yeah, in some important speeches and did some speech writing.
So, I expect we'll see some sort of version of that with Karl Rove.
He's not going to be going.
Just quickly, any chance that he'll be picked up by one of the many 2008 presidential candidates?
Well, it's not clear.
You know, he said he's not going to be a political consultant anymore.
And he said on the plane today, though, that he has friends in all the campaigns.
So he's making a point of reminding people how well connected he is.
But, you know, I don't know if there's a Republican candidate out there right now who wants to tie himself so closely to President Bush in bringing Karl Rove, but there's a long way to go.
Thank you, David.
Thanks, Michele.
That was NPR's White House correspondent David Greene.
He joined us from Iowa.
Last weekend, for our Science Out of the Box series, we took a tour of a city intersection and we asked you to post your pictures of the manmade world to an account we set up on the Web site Flickr.
We got more than 200 photos, and several came from Gail Dedrick.
In 1990, she moved from upstate New York to Manhattan.
Like many people new to the Big Apple, she looked up and was surprised to see rickety, shingled water towers on the roofs of many buildings.
And they just seemed so incongruous.
They kind of look like Petticoat Junction.
Like Monet with his haystacks, Dedrick started taking pictures obsessively.

I started noticing how they looked different depending on the time of day and whether it was stormy or wintery, and it was Flickr that made me realize I wasn't alone, that there was a secret society of people who just love water towers.
So on behalf of Manhattan's water tower enthusiasts, we want to know, how do they work?
We turn this question over to our expert on the industriosphere, Brian Hayes.
He's the author of ""Infrastructure: A Field Guide to the Industrial Landscape.
And just to be clear, we want the scoop on the water tanks in Manhattan, not the bulbous water towers in America's flatlands.
As Dedrick puts it...
If they're not wooden and they're not covered with shingles, they pretty much don't count.
Brian Hayes, what exactly are these water towers for?
Well, any building that's more than five or six floors high, if you had enough water pressure to reach the upper floors, you'd be bursting pipes down at the basement.
So for a long time, the city required that every building more than six stories high have its own tank on the top.
And there's a pump somewhere in the basement that all day and all night long moves water up to the roof; then when it's needed, it trickles back down.
(Through Translator) When the Father comes, we feel good because even though we're poor, he comes to visit us.
Father Givara is a spry, 70-year-old Jesuit.
He began coming to the dump 21 years ago.
But he doesn't just give spiritual support.
He started a charity that gives material help, too.
After Mass, he goes to a depressed neighborhood where many of the families who work at the dump now live.
As he walks through the dusty street, lined with houses made of concrete blocks, everyone greets him.
(Soundbite of children playing)
Inside one of the nicest buildings in the neighborhood, dozens of children play.
This is one of three day care centers that the Father has built.
There's also a clinic here.
He's received little material support from the Catholic Church.
His projects are the result of his efforts and fundraising.
Sitting in one of the classrooms, he talks of how he came to be involved with this community.
(Through Translator) the first time I went to the dump to give Mass, I was a Jesuit full of revolutionary fire and into social justice.
It occurred to me to ask one of them how much they earned.
It wasn't enough under the law, so I said, talk to your leaders so they pay you right.
I left feeling all pleased with myself.
And the people asked me to come back the following week.
But then, a messenger came and said that I would not be able to give Mass.
And I was banned from entering the dumps, because I had said things that were not convenient.
He had run afoul of the mafia-like leaders that control every aspect of life in the dumps.
But after the 1985 earthquake, he was asked to come back because body parts were turning up in the waste being deposited on the site.
The dump dwellers wanted him to give the remains a proper burial.
He slowly gained their confidence.
(Through Translator) These people are born and then live with crime and exploitation.
But I knew that I couldn't change that system, so it thought I'd have to respect it.
This brutal world, which has its own morality, is his own world now, too.
He's seen rival gang leaders kill each other.
He's baptized some of the 64 offspring of one of the dump kings who had 16 wives.
He knows that if a serious crime is committed, like stealing, the price is often a slit throat.
But still, Father Givara admires his flock's tenacity.
(Through Translator) I see them as people who are drowning, drowning victims of a society that has pushed them aside.
They will clutch a hold of anything to keep from going under.
And that gives me a lot of strength to keep going through my own hard times.
He says they support one another.
When the horse of a cart driver dies, he holds a party and every one eats the meat.
Still, at the daycare, workers talk of how many of the children have been sexually abused by their own families.
During these hours at the center, though, the children get three square meals, and more importantly, love.
He says he gives because he, too, receives.
(Through Translator) When I give a Mass, I am not giving a service.
I am receiving one.
I'm participating in their will power and faith, their love of life, and their capacity to keep fighting against all hope.
There's less hope here now than before.
The local government is selling the land on which the dump sits to developers.
No one knows what will happen next.
Father Givara's message, though, has been a simple one.
He tells them that he'll be there for them.
Whatever happens, he says they're not alone.
Lourdes Garcia Navarro, NPR News, Mexico City.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
Today marks an anniversary in the history of prostate cancer surgery.
Our co-host, Michele Norris, went to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore last evening and has the story.
Twenty-five years ago today, Dr. Patrick Walsh entered an operating room in Johns Hopkins Hospital and revolutionized the treatment for prostate cancer.
The year was 1982, and at that time, treatment options for prostate cancer were limited.
Surgery could control the disease, but it also created major side effects - extreme blood loss, no bladder control, and in all cases, impotence.
Dr. Walsh's surgical innovation was based on a suspicion that doctors did not really understand the complex tangle of veins and nerves that surround the prostate.
What I discovered were anatomic principles and those anatomic principles are now widely applied everywhere because it's the anatomy.
Urologists stop me at meetings and say thank you for developing that.
My patients are now able to have a safe operation.
And over the next 10 years, the mortality from the operation dropped tenfold.
(Soundbite of party conversation)
How are you?
Good to see you.
Yesterday, Johns Hopkins threw an anniversary party to honor the 69-year-old Dr. Walsh and the man known as patient number one.
I'd like to - this is the man of the hour - our first patient.
At this cocktail reception, two men seemed to smiling more broadly than almost anyone else in the room.
The fellow with the sparkling blue eyes and the small, pink whales on his tie - that's Dr. Walsh.
And a few steps away is his pioneering patient, a retired professor named Robert E.
Hastings.
(Soundbite of party conversation)
The two men are now friends.
But 25 years ago, they met for the first time as a weary cancer patient and a confident doctor.
Mr.
ROBERT E.
HASTINGS (Retired Professor; Former Prostate Cancer Patient): In my mind, a good surgeon has to have a good presence of himself, and I could see that right away.
So I know that this was more than two decades ago, but do you recall -was there something that Dr. Walsh said or something that he did that put you at ease?
That let you know that you were with the right man?
Well, I got a kind of a kick out of it, he just looked at me and said, you know, I can cure you.
And I said, well, that's what I like.
He's really positive, you know, no hemming or hawing.
He said, I can cure you, you know.
Now if can turn to Dr. Walsh.
This was 25 years ago, what was that confidence based on?

As I keep telling people, it's sort of a blessing and a curse in the nuclear industry and the radiation detection business that we can detect radioactive materials at extraordinarily low levels, which is a good thing, but it's also many orders of magnitude below where we would expect a threat.
And we know there is a global distribution of fission products and other products from weapons testing fallout.
So it's not surprising that they're finding it, and it's also not surprising that there might be some in the vicinity of the plant from the plant itself.
We're also told that there may be breaches in the containment boxes in some of these reactors and, indeed, in the pools where spent fuel rods are collected in some of the other reactors.
There are six altogether there at this facility.
And yet other people say this should calm down within time and not represent a real problem.
